author: kevaundray
content:
For a high level view of a vector commitment schemes: https://hackmd.io/@6iQDuIePQjyYBqDChYw_jg/HJOAXULw9

(Unfortunately, it assumes knowledge of how merkle trees work)

author: kevaundray
content: The idea is that binary merkle trees can be seen to have an in-efficient vector commitment scheme, which then allows us to realise a better vector commitment scheme which gives rise to verkle trees.

author: kevaundray
content: For information on the multipoint scheme being used, one can check here: https://hackmd.io/@6iQDuIePQjyYBqDChYw_jg/Skgv758D5

author: kevaundray
content: If you are unfamiliar with KZG style commitment schemes, the most important part to grasp would be how the factor theorem is used to prove openings for polynomials

author: kevaundray
content: See, the below screenshot. Happy to answer anyone with questions regarding this as the multipoint proof and I believe most multipoint proofs I've seen use it

author: kevaundray
content:
A simple optimisation to note: If your polynomials are in coefficient/monomial form, you can compute: 

q(X) = p(X) / (X - k) as this will equal q(X) = p(X) - r / (X - k)

author: kevaundray
content:
------

Since all polynomials are in lagrange basis and we want to open our polynomials at points on the domain, we get a division by zero scenario. In the previous screenshot, imagine `k` was a point in the domain and all polynomials are in lagrange basis.

To solve this, here I derived formulas that allow you to divide two polynomials f(X)/g(X) where g(X) is a linear factor of the vanishing polynomial, without using interpolation.

https://hackmd.io/@6iQDuIePQjyYBqDChYw_jg/B1FWLgtD9
